transport.comment:
It's hard to give you a favorite when there are so many good ones! It might help to know what category of EV you're looking at, since there are a large selection of EVs on the market right now with radically different sizes and limitations.

Are you looking for a small, inexpensive BEV with less than or equal to 100 miles of range? You'll want to look at the Focus EV, the I-MiEV, the Leaf, the Spark EV, the 500i. 

Are you looking for a no-compromise but pricy luxury BEV with hundreds of miles of range and incredible performance? There's the Tesla Model S.

Or are you looking for a standard-size vehicle with limited electrical range and a gas-burning range extender? There's the C-Max, the Fusion Energi, the i3, the MKZ, the Plug-in Prius, the Volt.

My personal favorite is the soon-to-end-production RAV4 EV, which is the only "mid-range" BEV on the market today - a standard-size RAV4 crossover with a speedy Tesla drivetrain and over 100 miles of range.

transport.comment:
I am in Chicago area, and know many of the PV installers here - I have even trained a few.  I and an installer put a 2.6 kW system in on my own house last year for .$7,800, and collected 55% in rebate and tax credit.  Wow!  I put in a similar system on a neighbor's house 5 years ago, and the completed price was $27,500!  So take the advice posted by kludgefactory, and get in while the getting is good.  

It is very unlikely you will zero out your ANNUAL sum for electric bill.  Of course, for some particular day or month, you may.  

Net metering in Illinois is like it is in most states:  If you do by golly generate more than you use by the end of your billing year, the surplus will apply to the following billing period or year.  But after another year, any surplus from that then previous year disappears.  

You should also look at signing on for RRTP (residential real time pricing) with ComEd.  I did so 5 years ago, and have saved about 20% on my costs without making much of any adjustment to my energy use.  ComEd would not allow combining both the Net Metering agreement and RRTP for several years, but they do now.  

Also, the Illinois rebate for PV (25%), though it is open for new applicants at the moment, is fickle.  It may close soon, and will stay closed until more money accrues in time.  Your contractor should be able to coach you on timing, etc., in this regard.  

Lastly, there is no selling of your REC available to individual homeowners in Illinois at this time, but keep an eye on the ISEA program for aggregating REC's.  In the past, they were the only authorized agent in Illinois to pay you for your RECs, and they may be able to start doing so again, or direct you on how to do it.  Last time they were able to payout, they paid about $200 per Megawatt-hour.  Your 2.2 mW system is likely to be able to produce between 3 and 4 mWh/per year, which once had value of $600 to $800 free income/year.

transport.comment:
Well, of course they don't have much of an effect.  One, there's not that many of them on the road, comparatively, and two, passenger automotive is not the only source of "pollutant emissions."  We are talking a fraction of a fraction, here.  

Still, in terms of energy efficiency, electric cars (and electric rail) use much less energy to get the same job done as fuel powered vehicles, because of the higher efficiency of electric motors.  There's less waste, and that's a good thing.

Are electric vehicles "good enough" to replace fossil fuel vehicles in every situation?  Hell no.  But they are good enough to replace *some* of the gas burning cars, and this is a good thing.

transport.comment:
> When was the last time you saw the government substantially raising taxes on the rich?

Dude, [the rich do not pay the most taxes, they pay **ALL** the taxes](http://www.cnbc.com/id/101264757)

> If you disagree with me then tell me how could the government possibly want climate change to be real or who else could be behind the "myth" of climate change.

There is a lot to say and I can't possibly touch every aspect of this issue, because it's very complex. Look up game theory. This is not about a conspiracy, it's about the interest of each player involved. The government wants to sustain itself, it's just the nature of government. Governments always grow bigger and more expensive, never smaller and more efficient. So if climate change helps towards that goal (more regulation, higher taxes, more control), the government will do it. Everyone has skin in the game. Corporations get cheap loand and tax credits (wind mills, solar panel companies, Tesla, etc), scientists get research grants, regulators get job security, etc. It's a very complex game and every player tries to maximize their own profit, whatever that means for them. The government doesn't **want** climate change to be real, the only thing that the government **wants** is to strengthen its power, but it's not because of some dark room secret meetings, it's because every person involved wants to keep her/his job and please her/his boss.

transport.comment:
Parity in this case is the minimum threshold where the loan cost meets and begins to be less than the $ saved.  Lets use your example:

$25K over 15 years @ 7% is a monthly payment of $225.

If you saved $1500 in your first year, you saved an average of $125 a month leaving you $100/mo below parity as I've defined it.

Oh wait! you say, you got a tax credit.  Lets assume your tax credit was 33%  (which it won't be that high, but it's a nice even number).

$16,750 over 15 years @ 7% is a monthly payment of $150.  Again, your electricity savings of $125/mo is less than $150.  Even at an annual electricity increase rate of 5% (which again, is wishful thinking for solar owners), you won't hit parity until quite a few years in leaving you a few years to make up the difference.

Again, my point all along here (and getting downvoted for it) is that getting a loan will not reach a financial parity (aka, your payment is <= savings) until you get a loan that's roughly 15+ years (which appears to be the case for you -- it's pretty close at 15 years, but still not quite there).

Again, it's not a "bad" deal to overpay for 15 years only to save (significantly) for the next 15, but it's not parity with the loan cost while you have the loan.  Additionally, states that have other benefits could throw this equation out the window.  I mean, if XX state wants to give you another $5K back, then sure - these numbers change, but I can't foresee all of those circumstances.  I qualify my statement with "in an area where you're only dealing with the federal tax credit."

transport.comment:
You have some good points about fanboysm, but the truth is that the acceleration is, by far, most interesting in the real life than the track capability. We have legal speed limits not to bother us but because physics is very cruel as speed goes up. So the acceleration is very useful to pass more safely slow cars or trucks, specially in countries like mine where there is a lot of hills and medium mountains where passing cars and trucks are a very dangerous challenge. For the track capability, I only see it being useful for German drivers in their Autobahns without speed limit, elsewhere it would be dangerous and only fast consuming power.
Unless you have ICE cars with a propulsive engines with more than one century of heavy investment from car-makers or Rimac which will cost you more than 1 million...
So, we should let Tesla, or others, perfect this infant technology (as the last Tesla 90D cars seems to show, and then the 100D even more) to be able to do high speed during more and more time without overheating. Be patient because, first (10 years ago) they were only "golf carts" with no acceleration (so very dangerous in the middle of real life traffic), now the acceleration beat all other cars, inclusive most of million dollars supercars. But for now, they overheat in tracks and have less range...YET. Let pass less than other 10 years, and then some will complain that EVs are good in acceleration, are good in tracks and have fairly good range but...they don't fly yet! Naysayers will stay naysayers until the end.

Also, EVs aren't notoriously inefficient at highway speeds, it is just a natural effect of drag where as you try to go faster it takes more energy to move the air out of the way. An EV is typically more efficient at highway speeds than an ICEV with lower drag coefficients. ICEVs are less efficient at lower speeds because they have to keep their engine running while moving slowly so their MPG is worse around town than on the highway where they're moving along with long gearing and the engine is typically running in the most efficient part of their power band. Even so, they still only use around 25% of the energy in the fuel they burn to move the car forward. An EV is more like 90% efficient at all speeds.

Interestingly, that makes the case that natural gas derived hydrogen is better. The efficiency of natural gas to hydrogen to FCV is very comparable to natural gas to electricity to BEV. It is especially true in context of gas peakers and not CCGT. If you use a battery to replace the gas turbine that also lowers the overall efficiency of the BEV cycle to be much closer than a overly simplistic analysis shows. 

The core article here is *VERY* simplistic, and has a lot of pretty out of date and/or pessimistic assumptions to get the well-to-wheels energy ratios they put up. I can show 10 year old anti-hydrogen papers that aren't even close to as pessimistic as this paper.

transport.comment:
> Is it too much to ask for multiple charge ports? 

I think it is. 

Copper is expensive and adding 2 of everything required for safely running DC charging probably isnt cheap. A lot of EV conversions dont even bother with DC charging and just stick with AC citing the cost of a DC system. Some early EVs actually had DC charging capability itself as an optional extra to help lower the cost which was sort of palatable given the smaller batteries.

transport.comment:
Wow a lot to digest here. The fraud alert is a one time thing that shouldn't be an issue.

No, range shouldn't be that bad with most EVs. You likely had the basest of the base model 3s, which only gets about 220mi of real world range on the highway in optimal conditions, and more like 150 in the dead of the winter. Turning off the HVAC heater can go a long way to extending EV range.

EVs are only a good choice if you can 95+% live off charging at home.

I always chuckle a bit when I hear how loud Teslas are at freeway speeds. Our Bolt EV is pretty much dead silent up until 70mph then the wind starts to pick up. Anything under that and an EV should be pretty much the quietest thing you've ever driven outside of a high end Merc. If it's not, that company is just doing a very bad job with sound insulation.

Seems like an EV is for you imo, but you need to get one with a better base range. Look into the steady 70mph freeway range tests to get a good gauge of what vehicles are actually meeting or exceeding their advertised range. If you want to stick with Tesla, best to open your wallet and get an AWD long range. Used Bolt EV with a factory replaced (under warranty) battery can be had for under $15K used... That would def get you comfortably through a 50mi round trip with home charging. 

Also remember that it's ok to drop to 40%. You just don't want to regularly go below 20%.

transport.comment:
I can certainly understand the appeal of trying to save money by doing a solar installation yourself. I was tempted to go the DIY route myself when I first started looking into solar. But after doing a lot of research and talking to both professional installers and DIYers, I ultimately decided that for my situation, hiring a reputable installer was the way to go. Here's why:  
  
1. Safety concerns: Working on a roof with high voltage electrical equipment is inherently dangerous if you don't have the proper training and safety gear. One misstep could lead to serious injury or worse. I'm fairly handy, but I recognized that this was beyond my skill level.  
  
2. Permitting and inspections: Getting all the necessary permits and passing the required inspections was a daunting prospect. My installer handled all of that paperwork and liaison with the city and utility. It was a big load off my mind.  
  
3. Warranty and support: My system came with a 25-year warranty on the panels and a 10-year warranty on the workmanship. If I had done it myself and something went wrong, I'd be on the hook for repairs. With my installer, I have someone to call if there's ever an issue.  
  
4. Optimizing the design: A professional designer was able to look at my unique roof layout, shading profile, and energy needs to come up with a system that maximized my production. I would have been guessing at the best configuration.  
  
5. Financing and incentives: My installer helped me secure a low-interest loan and guided me through claiming the federal tax credit and local incentives. That savings helped offset the cost of professional installation.  
  
Now, I'll admit I probably could have saved some money upfront by doing it myself. But for me, the long-term peace of mind that comes with a professionally installed and warranted system was worth the extra cost. I didn't want my roof to be a guinea pig for my first attempt at electrical work.  
  
That said, I know there are people out there who have the skills and risk tolerance to tackle a solar install. If that's you, then more power (pun intended) to you. But I would still advise doing a ton of research, getting very comfortable with the electrical aspects, having a solid plan for permitting and inspections, and being realistic about the time and effort involved. It's not a small undertaking.  
  
In the end, I was happy to pay a bit more to have experts handle it. My system has been cranking out the kilowatt hours trouble-free for five years now, and I've got someone to call if anything goes wrong. For me, that was worth a premium. But everyone has to weigh the tradeoffs for themselves.

housing.comment:
Assuming the normal Vmp is 0.5V/cell at 8A, the expected power is 60 cells\*0.5V=30V \* 8A = 240W.     

With a 20 C increase on a single cell, at -0.4%/C, makes that cell 0.42V, or 29.92V\*8A = 239W for the panel.          

If the manufacturer doesn't care about his reputation, but only about short term profit, he could sell it as a 235Wp panel.     
(*From what I understand, PV panels have a positive power tolerance only.*)      

It depends on how many bypass diodes you use in that panel, with 6 of them, a single cell failure takes out 10 cells (assuming a 60-cell panel), leaving you with 5/6 x 240W = 200W.     

If your warranty covers 'loss of production' it could make sense to replace that panel as soon as possible.

housing.comment:
Definitely not a clear line. Some integrators will work to break off the largest % of roofing costs to be designated solar construction. 
But of course they would, it is not their risk. Is all on owner who makes ITC/IRS filing. And, only whether is flagged for review among millions of applications - but during the elongated ~7 year clawback period. 
Replacing age-worn shingles to support solar array for example would not be allowable. But, adding structural elements to support increased lb/ft load for solar likely would be. 
I have not heard of a lot of bad outcomes/IRS audits happening on residential/small commercial system applications. But, understand IRS reviewers are trained to flag roof costs. 
In my business we have very serious accounting and legal consulting review services who parse every line item (as fun as it sounds)... There are definitely similar services/consultants for smaller projects - likely in the NJ-NY-CT axis (vs RI direct). 
Or start with your local SEIA - probably mid-Atlantic/NJ; but may be a NE chapter too. They could direct or ID supporting documentation. National SEIA has some good research materials. 

Without a doubt some portion of roof costs are included in many ITC applications - just want to ensure you are not outside the norm. Hope helpful. 
On the roof itself, ideal to somewhat integrate projects - roofer can install and seal needed penetrations at install time and then maintain warranty. Otherwise, if ballast, roof manufacturer may require slip sheet material to prevent abrasion of roofing surface (and require warranty inspection before/after to certify). From +7 years ago recall rubber/membrane roof manufacturers to be tougher of manufacturers to appease/maintain warranty - but that may have changed w increased installs etc. 

If you are seeking PPA the provider will deal will all these elements/risks. 

Love RI and (once) the RI market (I am in mid Atlantic) so hope you are able to build without incident and that my notes provide right level of caution/diligence needed on roofing - big tempting capex element. 

Ping as/if needed and good luck. G

housing.comment:
Not better, just different.

Scientists can make organic polymers or organic compounds that are strongly colored.  When something is colored, that means it is absorbing the incoming light.  Upon absorption of a photon (light) these organic materials (polymers, compounds) produce an electron that, with the help of the rest of the stuff in the device, can move easily to an electrode resulting in usable amounts of electricity.  For more info look at the wikipedia pages for organic photovoltaics or bulk heterojunction.

OPV has a broad application space due to its many unique characteristics.  OPV is thin, light weight, flexible, rollable, can be made in any shape, can conform to any surface, they are durable (not brittle), come in many colors, can be transparent to various degrees, are inexpensive to produce, environmentally friendly, recyclable, can be sewn into things, can be small or enormous in size, have a very low investment payback time, a very low carbon footprint to produce, they have a positive thermal coefficient (the hotter the better, to a point, whereas silicon does better in the cold), and OPV retains its efficiency at lower incident light levels (whereas silicon does not).  I'm probrably missing some stuff.

The point is, we need both silicon solar panels and OPV, and probrably many other solar technologies to have a complete solution.  For example, putting silicon solar panels on the side of a building is not economically viable, but OPV is perfect for that application space.  You'd never make a solar window out of a silicon panel because silicon is completely opaque, but OPV is semitransparent, making it perfect for certain window applications.  The list goes on and on.

I'm happy to answer any questions I can.

raw_responses.1.1.1_stance: Pro but lack of options (for OPV in certain applications where silicon is not suitable)

housing.comment:
A few major problems with that:

[Solar provided 0.6% of the energy for the US in 2015](https://www.eia.gov/energyexplained/images/charts/energy_consumption_by_source_2015-large.jpg) and with 260,077 workers in solar in [2016](http://fortune.com/2017/02/07/us-solar-jobs-2016/) added [39% capacity](https://www.greentechmedia.com/articles/read/us-solar-market-grows-95-in-2016-smashes-records) which would bring it up to 0.84% of total energy generation.

If it takes 260,000 solar workers 1 year to provide 0.24% of our power and solar panels last 25 years, then we are looking at around 6%.

Unfortunately, solar panels use [rare materials](https://e360.yale.edu/features/a_scarcity_of_rare_metals_is_hindering_green_technologies) and we should be seeing an impact on price before long.

housing.comment:
1  This article completely misrepresents what the INES is used for.  Already off to a bad start if that's their first assumption.  

It is using existing reactor designs which are mostly supposed to come offline in the next 20 years.  This would be ok for current risks, but to scale it out 60 years is totally dishonest.  most reactors being built now have passive safety systems.  The authors have no mention of new reactor designs or a detailed model of what happened at Fukushima.  They are working off "standard operating" assumptions rather than identifying the problems of those plants being below code, 1/10000 year tsunami, basement generators, outdated/non functioning conduit filters, insufficient auxiliary heat exchangers, ect. 

All of their data is based off plotting trends along the models they came up with.  They even mention at the bottom that multiple specialists have pointed out flaws in their methods but they insist on keeping their conclusions.  

It also does some statistical deception for example, counting multiple inconsequential immediately dealt with accidents over long periods of time (a container falling off a fork lift as a reportable accident) "accumulates" into a full scale melt down.  This is just pure dishonesty.  

The answer to meltdown fears will come in the form of building new reactors.  Otherwise more people will die from gas and coal pollution.

2 Its a centrifugal processing system, not a reactor that can get uranium ore into weapons grade materials.  Any country that wants to do this can do this without a nuclear reactor.  There is no causal mechanism between nuclear reactors for energy and nuclear weapons.  Stop assuming I agree with your flawed ideas.

3 Its the default consequence, I used Germany as an example.  You think you will be getting solar and wind but you end up with gas.  You will also need to bulldoze hundreds of thousands of acres of land to make solar farms or wind farms to match the output of one nuclear plant that sits on a few hundred.  Every time you see solar or wind farms, just remember the majority of that name plate is burning carbon.  This is common knowledge in the energy sector.
Educate yourself.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capacity_factor

The waste issue?  I already answered that. If you had your entire life powered by nuclear, the entirety of that spent fuel would fit inside a soda can.  scale that up to entire populations.  If it costs 50 billion for long term storage of all nuclear waste of an entire US, then its totally worth it.  I wouldn't want to waste it though because its fuel for gen 4 reactors.

Answer my question about the solar/wind waste.  

If you honestly think transmuting the materials will still be an issue in 100 years, you have no idea what you are talking about in terms of nuclear technology.  No one in the industry sees this as a major problem.  It is safe in the ground but more valuable in gen 4 reactors.  I would much rather take a large warehouse worth of nuclear spent fuel from an entire clean energy grid.  The alternative is dealing with mountains of toxic waste produced by wind and solar from a grid that is still mostly burning carbon in a world suffering from climate change with less wildlife and ecosystems due to the renewistan land footprint.   

"In other words, the land area dedicated to renewable energy ("Renewistan") would occupy a space about the size of Australia to keep the carbon dioxide level at 450 ppm."
https://www.wired.com/2009/01/renewistan/
This is taken from a much more in depth research book on the subjects.  It basically concludes advanced nuclear is our only option and we need to implement it fast.  

The nuclear example has already been achieved by 3 nations and others came close on a per capita basis.  Every other scenario is pretty much catastrophe.

Your dose of radiation from all nuclear energy activities averages out at fractions of a percent.  You are bathed in natural radiation from everything else.  

4 No source of energy is "viable" without government subsidies.  I explained this already and provided sources.  If you want to complain about government subsidies, look no further than wind or solar, they cost more and give less while keeping the carbon burning.  

In the US the nuclear industry comes out at a tax after all the regulatory hoops it needs to jump through, yet still remains competitive.  IT comes out to -27 billion after all the compliance measures are paid out.  BTW a huge chunk of those R&D subsidies were dedicated towards navy projects.  Others that were civ got blocked by fossil fuel backed politicians like the IFR in the 90s.  We had working walkaway reactors in the 90s ready to be built and the gov stepped in and shut everything down after spending billions.  
Exhibit 1:
http://www.misi-net.com/publications/EnergyIncentives-0517.pdf

You have that model backwards, Wind and solar are more expensive with externalities and buffering factored in.  You can cherry pick an article saying solar was "this cheap!" at high noon on a sunny day, but at night you are still burning carbon.  Renewables get feed in tariffs too, I already provided the model of Germany's spending on $300 billion + on renewables and how they get more expensive energy, higher emissions and could have carbonized their entire grid by now if they spent that money on nuclear.  
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesconca/2015/07/02/germanys-energy-transition-breaks-the-energiewende-paradox/#5e5593a63c2c

"Ambitious plans" don't prevent carbon from getting into the atmosphere.  I already provided links showing how their emissions went up despite spending 300+Billion on renewables and opened up coal plants.    Here is a direct link showing how those "ambitious plans" aren't even above a third of their planned track and new coal plants are opening up to compensate for these failures.  Using the "since 1990" example is a joke because France already mostly decarbonized by then.  The rest of the industrialized world could have done the same if people like you would stop fighting it.  Thanks for confirming that Germany did open up new coal stations after shutting down nuclear plants, here is an article explaining the hypocrisy of that situation.
http://www.dw.com/en/german-co2-emissions-targets-at-risk/a-18862708

The NASA article understands fundamental truths about energy systems.  Solar and wind are not reliable and always need carbon fuel backups as the majority of their name plate.  Hydro is already maxed out, geothermal is only safely feasible in shallow heat regions, mostly maxed out.  Nuclear is proven, reliable and safe.  Just 100 more nuclear plants in the U.S and we could have displaced carbon entirely.  If nuclear development was allowed to continue in the US, we could have been off grid carbon by the mid 90s. 

My sources are biased?  
That data came from the congressional budget office.  The source was listed right at the bottom of the graph.  

Your "baseload fallacy" is popularized by Mark Jacobson who had his models torn apart in the scientific community and now he wants to sue them because he was that humiliated.  He and his entire GCEP department is funded by exxonmobil and other fossil fuel giants.  Its funny how you accuse me of being "biased" when NASA and the CBO are my sources and you are parroting Jacobson's work who is backed by fossil fuels trying to sell this dangerous and unrealistic fantasy of 100% renewables.  This false narrative keeps their carbon burning while nuclear (their biggest competitor) gets shut down.

BTW here is the review he is suing for 10 mil over.  
http://www.pnas.org/content/114/26/6722.full

Mark's rebuttals demonstrates he doesn't understand or care to acknowledge basic fluid dynamics with the hydro example.  There are plenty of other blatant flaws in his models.  

I have spent many hours going over risk assessments and safety of all energy systems and I agree with the scientific consensus that advanced nuclear is the best way forward.  I support keeping hydro and geo systems in place, but they are location specific.  I don't support building new solar and wind because they keep the carbon burning and are environmentally catastrophic compared to nuclear.  When they are installed they are functionally decorations for carbon plants.  They don't scale and they require way more resources, money and land to operate while producing more waste.  Their EROI's are awful compared to nuclear which also outperforms fossil fuels by that metric.  
https://www.forbes.com/sites/jamesconca/2015/02/11/eroi-a-tool-to-predict-the-best-energy-mix/#460f5ed4a027

housing.comment:
I'm going to play Devil's Advocate, because sometimes an echo chamber just harms people too much:  
It is very easy and possible to be a worse environmentalist as a vegan than an omnivore. There are many factors. I'll list a few:  


the amount of travel by airplane  
having a gas-powered car instead of using a bike or mass public transportation  
not buying local produce (and pretending ten pounds of imported produce a week is not affecting anything)  
having multiple children instead of no children  
using hundreds of plastic diapers on said children  
buying new clothes for yourself, contributing to the second largest  pollution emitter on the planet, instead of second hand garments  
buying new clothes for the children instead of second-hand garments  
buying new technology instead of waiting 7 years to upgrade  
buying new cars, appliances, houses, etc  
living in a house instead of an apartment complex  
having a giant lawn instead of no lawn  
having a pool  
using pesticides in your lawn or community  
buying dozens of items on Amazon and having them shipped by freight, truck and car to your house each year  
having multiple pets that consume meat, grain etc instead of no pets  
being a smoker  
constantly dining out at fast-casual restaurants and using hundreds of plastic to-go containers each year  
not installing solar panels  
living in a state or country that requires daily heating of a home for 4 months of the year (such as UK or East Coast US)  
living in a state or country with insanely high heat that requires air conditioning 4 months of the year (Arizona, Nevada, etc)  
etc  


If your environmentalist friend is actively doing 30 actions to improve the world while you only are a vegan, then yes, their carbon footprint is probably half of yours. Being a vegan takes one car off the road, that's it. It's not hugely different than the other things listed above. Although all actions we do are better for humankind. Putting people down for not doing every single action just creates derision, depression, and giving up. Celebrate the victories your friend is doing and maybe that friend will teach you to improve as an environmentalist yourself.

housing.comment:
Personally, it's been the opposite. 

Propane tankless water heater is planned for the house, as well as a gas cooktop and gas oven. The reason is because: 

a) The solar capacity necessary to supply the water heater, cooktop, and oven would be quite beefy. It'd be real damn pricey, even though those things don't use that much power in the grand scheme of things (in terms of KWh per day). Since we can't sell back to the grid, anything I generate over what I'm using at any given moment either goes into batteries or just... doesn't get generated (technically) so it 'goes to waste'. So upsizing my solar array, batteries, and inverters to account for the 50 Amp draw of a cooktop and oven just doesn't make any sense at all financially.

b) The tankless water heaters are so much more efficient because they don't keep the large volume of water hot all day when I'm not using it, I'll use so little propane for it that the cost will be negligible... plus I can have as long a shower on a cloudy day as I want, without worrying about power usage.

I am considering a small induction cooktop, mostly for redundancy's sake, and because if (when) I have a lot of extra power on some days, cooking a meal on an induction cooktop could save me some propane (I guess, although a pretty small amount). Plus if something goes wrong with the propane system, I still have the other, and vice versa.

housing.comment:
Average is 3-5 years with SMR Nuclear Reactors (after permits). Also the LCOE cost is around $85 MW/h. One just got permitted in Idaho, I don't believe they've broken ground.

If you want to talk expensive, LCOE cost for batteries is $150 MW/h for only 4 hours of storage -- realistically you want closer to 18 hours of storage which is $675 MW/h LCOE add in Solar/Wind and you're over $700 MW/h.

You're already overproducing and losing efficiency on renewables in California, wasting all that land and destroying the ecosystem with Solar Power plants (rooftop is the only eco friendly solar). Germany has 9x the CO2 footprint as France, since France runs on Nuclear, despite them spending $580 billion. They've barely changed their carbon footprint since 2008, quite the waste of time and resources.[https://www.worldometers.info/co2-emissions/germany-co2-emissions/#:\~:text=Fossil%20CO2%20emissions%20in%20Germany,CO2%20emissions%20were%20765%2C922%2C900%20tons](https://www.worldometers.info/co2-emissions/germany-co2-emissions/#:~:text=Fossil%20CO2%20emissions%20in%20Germany,CO2%20emissions%20were%20765%2C922%2C900%20tons)

Here is a source for Cali, it has decreased roughly by 10% and that 10% is largely attributed to use of Gas (instead of Coal), which is a good part of the reason for Germany's modest decrease too:  
[https://energyathaas.wordpress.com/2018/05/21/are-californias-global-carbon-emissions-declining/](https://energyathaas.wordpress.com/2018/05/21/are-californias-global-carbon-emissions-declining/)

[https://ww3.arb.ca.gov/cc/inventory/pubs/reports/2000\_2016/ghg\_inventory\_trends\_00-16.pdf](https://ww3.arb.ca.gov/cc/inventory/pubs/reports/2000_2016/ghg_inventory_trends_00-16.pdf)

The issue is storage.... and without storage you have to burn fossil fuels or use Hydro for peak load (and there isn't nearly enough hyrdo -- which also comes with its own set of environmental concerns). Cali could use more Geo, but it's generally rare elsewhere in the world.

housing.comment: Honestly the Powerwall for me is basically equal parts tech geekery and bragging rights. There's a little peace of mind around knowing we'll have power through an outage but they also aren't frequent here. housing.comment:
totally agree. one thing thats good about mandatory solar on new builds and rooftop solar in general is that there is a huge amount of space immediately available for a build-out of an enormous amount of solar capacity with a number of benefits like existing grid interconnections but without all the negatives that come with large solar farms like destruction of habitat and land use. plus, this could benefit from economies of scale, as well as create better financing mechanisms like rolling the cost of panels into a low-interest home mortgage (well, if mortgage rates ever go back to what they were a couple of years ago)

youre right in a sense that utilities dont like small-scale solar too much, but i dont think its because they want to maintain control, since they can easily get ahead of the trend by, for example, setting up and managing local microgrids with neighborhood- or city-scale battery storage that individual homeowners cant really swing very easily. their problem is that for the last 150 years, the electric grid has been forced into a pattern of very large generating facilities and very-long-distance, very-high-throughput, and *very expensive* transmission networks, which is directly threatened by distributed generation.

Absolutely builders take advantage of it when people buy "because they just want it". That leads to all kinds of ways that builders cut costs that are not in the home owners best interest but that are legal.

housing.comment:
>So on the surface, at least, this is a technical dispute over battery safety and workforce training requirements. But just below the surface lurks a long-simmering conflict between the rooftop solar industry and organized labor.
>
If that sounds familiar, well, you probably read my latest story (which I still hope youll subscribe to The Times to access, if you havent already), or last weeks edition of Boiling Point. In both pieces, I noted that most rooftop solar jobs are nonunion, unlike most jobs building large-scale solar farms. Its a reality that has created constant tension in California, with politically powerful electrical and building trades unions pushing lawmakers to support big solar farms at the expense of rooftop installations.
>
The ongoing dispute over contracting standards is a revealing example of that tension.
>
>The idea of barring most rooftop solar companies from installing batteries  unless they also obtain an electrical contractors license, which requires employees performing electrical work to be certified electricians  was first proposed by the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers and the National Electrical Contractors Assn., whose member companies hire IBEW workers.
>
We cant comply with this. People will go out of business, said Bernadette Del Chiaro, executive director of the California Solar and Storage Assn. Prices will go up, and well lose the ability to meet customer demand for clean energy.
>
The CSLBs 11-3 vote reversed the boards earlier judgment that firms with C-46 solar contractors licenses could install batteries paired with solar panels. Del Chiaro said the about-face is especially damaging because homes and businesses that want solar increasingly want energy storage, too, to protect against wildfire-driven power outages and the threat of rolling blackouts.
>
When I called up folks on the other side of the debate to ask about all this, I got an entirely different version of events.
>
Eddie Bernacchi, a lobbyist for the National Electrical Contractors Assn., told me this is a dispute between electrical contractors and solar contractors over jurisdiction, not a union vs. nonunion issue. Requiring solar-plus-storage projects to be installed by contractors with certified electricians, he said, would not only improve safety, it would lead to higher wages in the solar industry.
>
The electrical contractors offer a path to higher wages and a real career, Bernacchi said.
>
Tom Enslow, an attorney representing the contractors association and IBEW, made a similar case. He said that while the new rule would allow union shops to better compete in the solar market, CSLBs decision was more about safety and precedent.
>
Whats happened is that the solar industry started pushing a theory that, hey, as long as we install an energy storage system at the same time, we should be allowed to do that work, Enslow said. Its pretty clear they are separate systems.
>
Those arguments seemingly convinced the state board. Nancy Springer, the chief building official for Sacramento County, said she and her fellow board members have to be aware of protecting the consumers and making sure that theyre installed properly, and that people have the proper training. Board member Johnny Simpson, who previously led an IBEW local and was appointed by the Senate Rules Committee, responded to calls for more debate by saying, Its time to put this issue to bed.
>
I also spoke with Carol Zabin, who leads the UC Berkeley Labor Centers Green Economy Program and co-authored a report that helped prompt CSLBs decision. She said she and her team  which included a chemical safety expert  found little difference between the cost of a solar system installed by a firm using certified electricians and a firm not using certified electricians.
>
Its about whether you want a certified workforce or not, Zabin said. They have no certifications in that industry.
>
Suffice to say the solar industry pushed back against those claims, hard.
>
Barry Cinnamon, CEO of Bay Area solar and battery installer Cinnamon Energy Systems, said the idea that companies like his dont train their workers to handle energy storage systems is absurd. The companies that manufacture lithium-ion batteries  such as Enphase, LG and Tesla  also require workers who install their products to sit for several hours of training, Cinnamon said.
>
You have to be trained, or they wont sell you the battery, he said.

https://www.latimes.com/environment/newsletter/2021-11-11/why-are-are-unions-clashing-with-solar-industry-on-clean-energy-batteries-boiling-point

housing.comment:
Why do you think you can make the decisions of a forever change in their community when you dont live there? There are many reasons why some communities push back . Do you know first hand how the developer operates? Any history of broken contracts ? Abandoned sites? How many homes will be affected ? If you spent hundreds of thousands of dollars to build your dream home only to be surrounded by a solar power plant that tanks your property value , how would you feel? Yes people have property rights but every jurisdiction has zoning laws and special use permits . Is it farmland ?USDA Prime? What about flooding ? Many developers have been sued for nefarious practices  Renewables have a place in the path to energy futures but they need to be permitted properly and integrated into communities so the residents are protected . Reasonable setbacks and acreage caps in zoning laws keep developers in check . And why do developers think they can just choose an area and cover it with panels and the community should roll out the red carpet , and when there is any kind of pushback or alternative offer ( negotiation) from a community , the developers refuse to negotiate and sue   It is a David against Goliath scenario   The process starts 3 years before anyone except leased land owners know anything , everything is covert , then 3 years later developers drop the proposal on town hall and they are supposed to then TRUST a company to operate on the up and up ? Seriously ? You need to research developers more and not rush to shove covering farmland with solar panels on a community you dont even live in.

If you are passionate about renewables start at YOUR home and YOUR community  A one size fits all approach does not work on forever planning decisions

>The Society was formed in 1944 by a group of vegetarians who recognised the ethical compromises of eating eggs and dairy products.

Yep. The first 1944 definition only talked about dairy, in fact, not eggs. Since then the redefined it to exclude eggs and then in 1951 all other animal products. food.comment:
You and your dictionary are trying to make a very strange and pedantic point here.
  
  
If I say X "doesn't cut it" I'm saying that X doesn't meet my expectations in the given context.  If I say "I prefer Y to X", I'm saying Y better meets my expectations in the given context.
  
  
Whether X has zero value or not, both statements can still be true. There is no contradiction.
   
  
On your **bold** part, you're saying the existence of a certain kind of research will prove the already-obvious point that the vast majority of researchers don't get to study only things they're personally invested in.  Obviously that wouldn't prove anything, there are lots of factors besides researchers' own interests that dictate what gets studied.
  
  
On the stuff about cat food ingredients, etc... I dunno, you're kind of wearing me out with all that text.  But I think you may be trying to blur the distinction between feeding a cat some meat, and feeding a cat no meat.  Does not compute.  Two very different things - one is vegan, one is not. 
  
  
Finally, if you're unclear about the moral distinction between buying a can of non-vegan pet food and abusing a pet, then I suggest you ask a psychiatrist.

The victims of "hunters" (read: serial killers who prey on animals because it's still legal) often die horrible, terrifying, painful deaths; especially when they escape with a wound that causes them tremendous pain for a long period of time before killing them.

Factory farming may be worse than "hunting" but, in your attempt to make this point, be careful not to make "hunting" sound more innocent and humane than it actually is.  
Also keep in mind that we don't have to choose one or the other. We can dismiss both "hunting" and factory farming as horrendous and unacceptable.

food.comment:
> can you tell me why you aren't?

It has to do with me experience with organic farming and my quest for knowledge, I actually got interested where my food came from and from my days of veganism to now I will admit I despise the *city vegans*, which are 99% of them.

Man, I remember, *The China Study* was my bible, people with heart disease in my opinion *had it coming* for consuming animal products and I thought my choice was the best thing for my health, the enviroment and the future of humanity. Smug. Little. Shit.

I was wrong in every single instance, I was so wrong I look back in disbelief, I see myself in every single vegan I encounter here on reddit, I see a more ignorant self who can only be described as a naive teenager.

The first thing I came to realize is that modern agriculture is the single greatest disaster the world has ever seen, Norman Borlaug and Fritz Haber have done more damage to this earth than anything else in the past 70,000 years, the green revolution was a mistake.

We are pumping fossil fiels into our food, then we transport and package said food with more fossil fuels, the whole process uses so much energy and creates so much greenhouse gas I came into another realization: The world could go vegan and 200 species would still continue to be driven into extinction every. single. day.

Is was with that realization that I understood that going vegan by itself would not save anybody from anything.

So I got myself to try, I said to myself, *you can prove that wrong, I can be vegan and be green!*, I failed miserably, green manure is almost worthless, I create a pathetic version of a maize plant... So I had to do it the right way.

The mission: Start by growing a 1 year supply of maize with cow manure.

I understood then that this animals were necessary for me to survive, their shit was gold, so I collected 1 m3 of cow manure and composted it with some hay, 2 weeks later, the manure was ready, I was happy, no animals died and I had enough compost for the maize.

I planted the maize and the ranch's cowboy did the rest of the work so he could get part of my maize harvest. It would take around 4 months until harvest time so I came back time to time just to see it grow, and in one of those day I came into another realization, a cow was terribly sick because of a virus that it got from bats, it had to be put down, I realized, not only were that cow necessary for the maize, but as a vegan, it's natural death would serve no purpose, I could not eat a single bite of that cow, between my almost-religious veganism and the stupid-ass idea that saturated fat is bad for human consumption, I remained vegan.

2 months later, another realization, I accidentally found a deer that had starved to death, because of the drug war (mexico), hunters no longer came this season and without predators, the deer population exploded, there where so many deer tons of them just starved to death and some others got sick and just wandered around until they dropped, it was horrible, I quickly saw what happened to prey when not predated, which was the following and most powerfull revelation to me, hunting was necessary and it was not only necessary, but humane, a deer population kept in check is a much better alternative to the disgusting mess that results from lack a predation, and what better predator than a 30-06? Nature will never provide such a quick and clean death than the human hunter, this realization, slowly but surely, started breaking down my view on veganism.

The final blow to my veganism: 2 week before harvest the rancher told me the neighbors maize (over 4 tons) was completely destroyed by badgers in just 1 night. It was war against the badgers, the following night, with flashlights and bait, the cowboy shot 13 badgers with an air rifle.

I was done with veganism! 13 animals died in my quest for vegan self-reliance, if those 13 animals would have been cows, I would have enough meat for years!

After that I remember how wrong I was, I felt like a pathetic idiot who derserved a slap, veganism became truly naive in my eyes and I developed resentment agains vegans, all vegans deserve to experience what I did, and we'll which ones are smart enough to change their mind.

The corn I harvested then was sold because of my realization, but it keeps me thinking, I'm sure there some vegan out there that ate some of it, maize that took 13 animal lives to create and now that some smug vegan proudly munches one, truly disgusting!

I then found something beatiful and that truly has potential to save mankind, permaculture or in other words organic polyculture, aquaculture and sustainable developement.

I was not vegan not even a single part of it, permaculture design needs animals to function.

I came into the realization that semi-vegetarianism was the only acceptable form of vegetarianism, chickens produce a super-food almost every single day and cows too, animal products are extremely superior in almost every regard to plants and grains.

There is literally no reason why I would ever go back to veganism, I find it naive and most of the time just repugnantly ignorant.

Veganism is a fad, that's my final realization, good night.

food.comment:
Completely agree that  BLM should not be forced to include veganism. This is related to why Im not pro-intersectionalism with animal rights (veganism) regarding the inclusion of human animals into veganism, at least not the way that Ive seen it in practice. While it is good to have some intersectional considerations in BLM (women, disabilities, LGBT), to go off and start talking about LGBT rights is an utter distraction that brings the focus away from black lives. With animal rights, shifting the attention to human animals not only takes up space that was created to rescue non-human animals from humans but detracts from the unique reasons that non-human animals need help with which humans have nothing in common:  being eaten and being used for fashionable clothing. We do have a tenuous shared struggle with unjust experimentation and entertainment, but again, most cases are radically different. Humans and animals do share some other forms of exploitation like forced labor, but again, human issues take up less of the *very* limited space that veganism takes up takes up in public and online discourse. 

Animals cannot create websites or spread awareness of their abuse to others like humans can, so the only advocacy for animal rights occurs during the time that humans are speaking or doing other activism on their behalf. Since humans are not only able to share their stories of oppression and even speak up in public discourse for themselves (not mention participate in advocacy), it seems just to allow discussions of animal rights to focus on those who dont have the ability to speak for themselves and experiences horror on a massive scale. It may be worth it to incorporate discussions of humans if it serves to protect animals from the various forms of exploration they face. food.comment:
As for protein, when I first went vegan I leaned heavy on the meat substitutes (gardein, beyond etc.) 

But, I have found myself getting tired of all the processed stuff. If you are looking for more cleaner whole foodsie kind of proteins that still have that satiating flavor and bite here is my list:


* Soy curls: Cooks like chicken or beef strips. Seasoned well these are so good. I just received a 12 lb box of them. 

* Tempeh: Marinate and season well. Cooks like chicken or beef strips. Crumble it into a chili, get creative. 

* Seitan: My favorite is Field Roast, they do it right. Great bite and flavor - only contain ingredients that you can understand.  

* Homemade bean burgers: Make them with a bit of flour or vital wheat gluten to make them hold together better and have a better bite.

Edit: how could I forgot **tofu**. Buy firm tofu and cut into small chunks and marinate. Coat with a little bit of oil and corn starch and bake, or preferably, air fry.

food.comment: I know this can be very different based on where you live, but I don't go to restaurants anymore if I have to make modifications to make the dish vegan. Not only do they often get things wrong when modifications have to be made, I don't like being taken advantage of like you mention. I don't like paying full price for something when I'm omitting the most expensive ingredients. There are too many places now that take their vegan customers seriously and offer suitable options for me to bother with places that do not. I either go to go places that are 100% vegan or have dedicated vegan options on their menu that can be ordered unmodified.
